title: Tuesday, 10th April, 2018
bodyHTML:
Alchemy30 Morning
11:05 am
BE11:06am

Hello. Hi. Welcome. Good morning.

Blank canvas good morning everyone

Soundbuy Morning all...........
DRichi Good morning all
Grouchmonkey Morning all
OnYourRight Morning all
AAAA Bonjour les amis !

Markets Live. FT Alphaville's etc.

Pi1010 hi

Morning!

Maverick Guten Morgen

Petrofac Ltd (PFC:LSE): Last: 529.80, up 10.8 (+2.08%), High: 530.80, Low: 520.80, Volume: 451.95k

A bit of closure would be good for them. There's a refinancing due later this year, if memory serves

DM11:11am

Must be a hard sell to bond investors. "under use of proceeds you've got reparations down here, is that right?"

Mouselet Good morning people
11:12 am

Although, there is also a chance it comes to naught, of course.

Can't wait to hear anything on Globo, and Quindell, remember them?

soldsoldsupersold any vision on the russian stocks getting hammered on the london international exchange?

chad_john @DM I think the SFO left Quindell to the FCA. Or was it vice versa.

Hm.

11:13 am

................. Hm.

DM11:14am

@chad_john vicer versa

chad_john @DM Ah, thanks.
Soundbuy @ Grouchmonkey - did they react to last Wetherspoons' cautious comments re costs etc going fwd?
11:14 am
undefined
BE11:14am

So -- pubs getting a lot of attention on the right.

BE11:15am

News is that it snowed last month.

11:15 am
DM11:15am

Did it! How's the market taking it?

BE11:15am

Badly. Apparently, investors need Barclaycard data do tell them that rather than -- for example -- looking out the window.

BE11:16am

Here's the Barclays spend trend report .....

11:16 am
BE11:16am

March was one of the weakest months for Pubs & Restaurants, as operators suffered from the poor weather. On a short-term basis, this poor performance could create negative reactions in share prices of the pubs stocks as they update the market on trading. Yet ultimately this does not change our fundamental view on any stock. We maintain our preference for names where we perceive greater balance sheet strength (JD Wetherspoon and Greene King, both OW, vs Marston’s and Mitchells and Butlers, both UW rated).

BE11:17am

Overall, consumer spending growth fell to +2.0% y/y. Lowest rate of growth in two years, down from +3.8% in February and well below the three-month average of +3.2%.

BE11:17am

You've also got Stifel cutting forecasts for both Marston's and Mitchells, which are leading us down.

Mouselet I am surprised that Wetherspoons is not a dividend stock (1% yield)
11:17 am
Mitchells & Butlers PLC (MAB:LSE): Last: 247.80, down 14.4 (-5.49%), High: 266.60, Low: 247.00, Volume: 110.32k
Marston's PLC (MARS:LSE): Last: 96.15, down 5.45 (-5.36%), High: 102.00, Low: 95.90, Volume: 3.47m
red think march a weak month all around for retail sales
BE11:17am

Both remain buy though ......

Grouchmonkey @soundbuy not sure if its directly related, but they did have a bump down in mid-march.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

[Marston's] shares have been disappointing performers due to modest but continual downgrades to forecasts and concerns over rising debt levels. First half profits will have been impacted by severe weather conditions and we reduce our full year pre-tax forecast by £2.5m to £108m. We believe that management should consider reducing the capital spending programme further with a view to generating a positive cash flow after dividend payments. We consider this would improve investor confidence levels towards the shares, which look oversold with a dividend yield of 7.5%.

DM11:18am

Well they are a lot cheaper today

BE11:18am

.... and ........

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Mitchells & Butlers continues to increase market share but the actual performance in H1 will inevitably be impacted by adverse weather. Accordingly we reduce our pre-tax profit forecasts by £5m. The shares are a special situation given the dividend uncertainty, but the rating looks low on both earnings and asset considerations.

red if you take out earlier easter bump then not good at all
BE11:18am

.... so. That's pubs.

undefined
chad_john Anything more on Mothercare and the possible CVA?
11:19 am
DM11:19am

Where next, East?

BE11:19am

I guess so. It rumbles on.

Cloudy @Mouse Tim Martin vs HMRC tax on his div is why it 1%.
BE11:20am

Today we get the second-order effects, such as Glencore

11:20 am
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 345.25, up 6.1 (+1.80%), High: 354.60, Low: 343.70, Volume: 27.34m
BE11:21am

Glencore notes the designation of United Company Rusal Plc ("Rusal") and EN+ Group Plc ("EN+") as Specially Designated Nationals ("SDNs") by the United States Government.

Glencore has various contracts with Rusal for the purchase of aluminium and alumina.

Glencore is committed to complying with all applicable sanctions in its business and is taking all necessary measures in order to mitigate any risks to Glencore's business as result of the designation of Rusal and EN+ as SDNs, including in respect of secondary sanctions.

Mr. Glasenberg has resigned from his position as a director of Rusal.

Glencore is still evaluating the position under its contracts with Rusal, but notes that these contracts are not financially material to Glencore.

Glencore has previously signed a non-binding term sheet with EN+ regarding swapping its shares in Rusal for Global Depositary Receipts in EN+ (the "Transaction"). Glencore will not proceed with the Transaction at this time in light of the designation of Rusal and EN+ as SDNs.

RA keen for glencore news
Maverick Light touch on Sainsburys for MTC on the 5th. Large pinch of salt comes to mind
BE11:22am

Also, news on the tape that Russia's pulled the ruble-bond auction due to go tomorrow.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

But back to Glencore -- argument here is that direct exposure's pretty slim .....

BE11:23am

At least in terms of marketing, which JP Morgan Caz spells out.

BE11:24am

Russian-sourced Marketing EBITDA is c.1% Group spot 2018E: Based on media publications and company disclosures, Marketing EBITDA sourced from Russian agreements is generated within: (i) Metals & Mining (~US$90-100m pa); (ii) Oil & Gas (~US$90-120m pa); and (iii) Agriculture (~US$15-20m pa). On a combined basis, this is equivalent to ~US$200-240m or ~1% of GLEN’s spot 2018E EBITDA.

FATDAZ @BE interesting that the Pubs data is in complete contrast to the BRC data out over night that showed retail sales up by 1.4% LFL and 2.3% in total in March quite a disconnect
11:24 am
BE11:24am

But then you have the offtake agreement with Rusal ....

BE11:24am

.... where Ivan was until today a non-exec .....

December69 - Sceptic @FatDaz money only goes so far
BE11:25am

M&M exposure is ~US$90-100m pa EBITDA: In Metals & Mining, GLEN has a 7-year offtake agreement for primary aluminium & alloys with Rusal which expires at YE’18 (there are no details on any extension clauses). The agreement had a total sales value of US$2.4bn in 2017 or ~1.0-1.5Mt of annualised volumes. Applying GLEN’s historical margins of ~3.7-3.9% in metals marketing, we estimate the agreement contributes ~US$90-100m pa EBITDA.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

.... oh, and he's still on the board of Rosleft, where Glencore has a 25% stake.

BE11:26am

As well as marketing rights to 220kbbl/d production over five years

11:26 am

BE11:27am

There's also a 100% owned “International Grain Company” subsidiary, which is one of Russia's biggest grain exporters. ~2.5Mt of grain exports in 2016, reportedly.

Philruffin any views on sberbank?
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Based on Friday’s close, GLEN’s 8.75% Rusal stake was worth
~US$930m (before the c.40% fall today), ~US$700m attributable from its 25% Russneft stake and ~US$290m from its 0.50% ownership in Rosneft. We calculate the reduction in equity value attributable to GLEN post US sanctions being announced is ~US$0.5bn of which ~80% relates to Rusal. Based on consensus and in-house forecasts, we estimate the aggregate 2018E total dividend stream from these companies attributable to GLEN at
~US$60m.

FATDAZ @LJ again a good point but drink and cigarettes historically have had an inelastic demand curve such that price and other factors rarely put people off them

kemche Salmon trousers and brown brogues for me. Just so as not to be "demonstrable".

11:50 am
BE11:50am

And there have been all sorts of rumours of late that Ingenico's a target, with Atos the company usually mentioned.

Mouselet red: I think it may be you I have to thank for suggesting Poland as an investment destination. Thank you.
Miss Piggy #watches: I can't resist a clip, Chris Walken tells little butch about the gold watch (Pulp fiction) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFtHjV4c4uw
BE11:51am

So ..... clear and obvious readthrough, Ingenico's up about 6% this morning.

BE11:51am

Kepler incoming ....

11:51 am
BE11:51am

The multiples paid by the private equity funds are fairly generous at 15-16x 2018E P/E and 13-14x 2018E EBIT, taking into account the poor track record of the company and the lack of visibility on the payment terminals business mid-term. Verifone just initiated a gradual turnaround following a large number of badly integrated acquisitions, and its share price was close to the bottom (lowest point since 2009). The outlook for 2018 was mixed with limited top-line growth (+1-3% LFL) but solid operating margins improvements (14%, up 270bps). While we believe the multiples paid are fairly generous, the deal nevertheless shows that there is value within the POS terminals business, and this is positive for Ingenico.

red @Mouseletthere are some good ops in poland and it keeps you on the right side of the brexit hedge
BE11:52am

While Ingenico now trades on 12x 2018E EBIT and 13.4x 2018E EBIT, applying Verifone’s takeover multiples to Ingenico could lead to c. EUR77-78 per share (about 15% above the current share price). It is fair to say that Ingenico has a much better track record and profile than Verifone with services already representing 50% of sales today and transaction management services c. 40% (online and in-store processing). While the acquisition of Verifone should raise speculative appeal on Ingenico, we are not sure that private equity funds in Europe are ready to launch a bid on Ingenico in the short term, due to the lack of visibility on the payment terminals outlook for the mid-term (we should have clearer view by the end of the year) and the fact that private equity funds in Europe have mostly chased payment services providers with large exposure to recurring processing revenues (like Worldpay, NETS, Paysafe, Payvision).

Flaneur Ms Skripal leaves hospital, I see.Hope she remembered her watch ;)
Mouselet https://www.hodinkee.com/articles/frederique-constant-hybrid-manufacture-smartwatch-introducing exists
BE11:52am

And Mirabaud's Campling.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

The deal for Verifone serves as a reminder of the significant dry powder in PE. Preqin estimates that private equity firms are sitting on more than $1 trillion in uninvested capital which they will need to spend if they want to earn the hefty fees they collect on investment gains. Verifone’s execution has been patchy at best in recent quarters having missed consensus EBIT estimates in five of the last ten quarters. We would argue that Ingenico’s technology and execution are both superior to Verifone, with Ingenico having gained significant market share in payment terminals in recent years, particularly in the US market. Ingenico has also expanded into the payment services market to increase its recurring revenue stream.

Fintech M&A is on the rise with the Verifone deal following the ongoing bidding “war” for Fidessa and the $17B Blackstone strike for Thomson Reuters data unit. Ingenico’s valuation now has a future implied growth rate that is negative; suggesting that it will grow revenues in perpetuity at -0.7%. And the valuation is now trading at -1SD below 30 year trend. We can’t help but wonder if the same will prompt interest. The combination of recurring services, attractive valuation, strong market position and best in class solutions could well find Ingenico next on the shopping list, whether the buyer be from either PE or industry.

Mouselet 'Preqin estimates that private equity firms are sitting on more than $1 trillion in uninvested capital' is not a figure I'd heard before and is really quite a terrifying figure
BE11:53am

BE11:54am

What the Verifone deal tells us:
1) Private equity is willing to pay substantial premiums for listed payment system players;
2) The price paid by Francisco Partners implies 12.0/10.0x consensus 2018/19 EV/EBITDA respectively, 14.0/11.8x EV/EBIT and 15.6/13.3x P/E. Ingenico is currently trading on 10.1/8.7x EV/EBITDA, 12.5/10.7x EV/EBIT and 12.1/10.5x P/E.
3) Ingenico’s free float is c. 95% but the fact that France’s Sovereign fund BPI holds a 5.35% stake may be perceived as barrier to a private equity bid.
Conclusion The wave of consolidation could stoke up investor interest in Ingenico (inc PMs), not least as the stock is deeply undervalued in our view. At the latest closing price of €67.88, the stock trades at a 20% discount to its average 2009-17 EV/Sales, EV/EBITDA, EV/EBIT and PE multiples.
